rows.FLASH TEAMS MODEL: Stanford flash teams applied to the Trade. Small sprints. Tiny equity. People flash in and flash out.
THE MODEL
Reference: Stanford HAI — 'Flash Teams: The Future of Agile Collaboration'
(Valentine & Bernstein, MIT Press, 2025)
Flash teams are groups of experts who assemble quickly for a specific project
and dissolve when the work is complete. Members may never have met.
Assembled through platforms based on expertise. Coordinated by software.
Applied to the Trade:
• Nobody has a big job. Everyone has a small, scoped sprint.
• A PM co-founder doesn't 'run a cluster for 3 months' —
they flash in, produce 4-6 TUPs over 2-3 weeks, and dissolve.
• An expert doesn't 'join the team' — they review for 10-20 hours and leave.
• The MC does a burst of conversations for a cluster and moves on.
• Equity is tiny per person because the job is tiny per person.
• You might have 40-60 people touch the Trade, each for a short burst,
rather than 14 people for a long commitment.
The Trade itself is the coordination software. It tells each person what to do,
what 'done' looks like, and who they're handing off to. The librarian is the
platform operator. The MC is the onboarding and offboarding ritual.
INVESTOR NARRATIVE: 'We assembled a 103-model operating system using
Stanford's flash teams model. 40+ experts, globally distributed, assembled
on-demand, coordinated by the Trade, dissolved when done. Zero payroll.
That IS the coordination thesis in action.'
TWO TYPES OF ROLES
Type
PERSISTENT
rows.col_2: Stays for the full production cycle. Small scope but ongoing. The connective tissue.
rows.col_5:
Librarian (Elaine): custody of the Trade, ongoing
Conductor: ops and logistics, ongoing
MC: conversations across all clusters, ongoing

rows.FLASH TEAMS MODEL: FLASH
rows.col_2: Comes in for one sprint. Produces a specific deliverable. Dissolves. May never interact with anyone else except the MC and the librarian.
rows.col_5:
PM co-founder: produces 4-6 TUPs in 2-3 weeks, done
Expert reviewer: 10-20 hours over 2 weeks, done
Product person: builds site in 2-3 weeks, done
Danilo: writes a specific essay when asked, done
Funnel builder: sets up YouTube funnel, done
Series producer: plans narrative arc, done

rows.FLASH TEAMS MODEL: HOW FLASH SPRINTS WORK
1. SCOPE: The P-tab for each TUP already defines the sprint. What to produce, what 'done' looks like.
2. FIND: Conductor sources the person via platforms (Upwork, LinkedIn, communities) or referrals.
3. MC CONVERSATION: The MC has an on-air conversation with the person. This is the 'interview'
AND the onboarding. Recorded, published. The person is now on the cast page.
4. LIBRARIAN HANDOFF: Elaine prepares their working folder. INSTRUCTIONS.md + their tabs.
Full Trade available read-only for context.
5. SPRINT: They produce. 1-4 weeks. Claude available as co-pilot. MC checks in weekly (recorded).
6. SUBMIT: They drop finished work in their SUBMIT folder. Librarian updates master.
7. MC CLOSING: MC has a closing conversation. 'What did you build? What surprised you?'
This is content AND offboarding.
8. DISSOLVE: They're done. Cast page shows their contribution. They keep portfolio rights.
They may flash back in for a different sprint later.
Total touch time per flash person: MC conversation (30 min) + sprint (10-60 hours) +
MC closing (20 min). That's it. No meetings, no standups, no Slack channel.
EQUITY BUDGET (FLASH MODEL)
If 40-60 people each get 0.1-0.5% per sprint:
Low end: 40 people × 0.1% = 4%
High end: 60 people × 0.5% = 30%
Realistic: ~50 people averaging 0.25% = 12.5%
Persistent roles (3 people × 1-2%) = 3-6%
Total equity distributed pre-raise: ~15-20%
Danilo / Studio 4 retains: ~50-60%
Option pool: ~10-15%
Investor dilution from seed (15-25%) comes off everyone pro rata.
Post-raise, PM co-founders on the operating side can become full-time paid roles.
The flash model is for the IMAGINATION PASSET production phase.
Once funded, the IMPLEMENTATION PASSET is run by paid operators.
